title: Table 1: % Children enrolled in different types of schools. By age group and sex. 2024
description: This table provides a detailed breakdown of school enrollment percentages for children in India for the year 2024. It categorizes enrollment by school type (Government, Private, Other) and includes the proportion of children who are not enrolled in school. The data is further segmented by various age groups (6-14, 7-10, 11-14, 15-16) and by sex, allowing for a comparative analysis of enrollment patterns.
data: | Age group and sex | Govt | Pvt | Other | Not in school | Total |

title: Table 2: % Children enrolled in different types of pre-schools and schools. By age. 2022
description: This table presents the distribution of school and pre-school enrollment for children aged 3 to 8 in India for the year 2022. It breaks down the data by specific age, showing the percentage of children attending different types of institutions, including Anganwadi, government pre-primary classes, private LKG/UKG, as well as government and private schools. It also includes the percentage of children not enrolled in any educational institution.
data: | Age | Pre-school | Pre-school | Pre-school | School | School | School | Not in pre-school or school | Total |
| Age | Angan-wadi | Govt pre-primary | Pvt LKG/UKG | Govt | Pvt | Other | Not in pre-school or school | Total |

title: Table 3: % Children enrolled in different types of pre-schools and schools. By age. 2024
description: This table shows the percentage of children aged 3 to 8 in India enrolled in various educational settings for the year 2024. The data is categorized by the child's age and institution type, covering Anganwadi centers, government pre-primary, private LKG/UKG, government schools, and private schools. A column for children not enrolled in any pre-school or school is also included for a comprehensive view.
data: | Age | Pre-school | Pre-school | Pre-school | School | School | School | Not in pre-school or school | Total |
| Age | Angan-wadi | Govt pre-primary | Pvt LKG/ UKG | Govt | Pvt | Other | Not in pre-school or school | Total |

title: Table 4: % Children by grade and reading level. All children. 2024
description: This table assesses the foundational reading abilities of students across India for the year 2024. It provides a grade-wise breakdown (Standard I to VIII) of the percentage of children at different reading proficiency levels, ranging from not recognizing letters to being able to read a Standard II level text.
data: | Std | Not even letter | Letter | Word | Std I level text | Std II level text | Total |

title: Table 5: Trends over time
description: This table presents a longitudinal analysis of reading proficiency for Standard III students in India from 2014 to 2024. It specifically tracks the percentage of children in Standard III who are able to read a Standard II level text, with data separated for government schools, private schools, and a combined total.
data: | Year | % Children in Std III who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std III who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std III who can read Std II level text |

title: Table 6: Trends over time
description: This table shows historical trends in reading comprehension for students in Standards V and VIII across India for the years 2014, 2016, 2018, 2022, and 2024. It documents the percentage of students in these two grades who can successfully read a text intended for a Standard II level, broken down by government schools, private schools, and a combined average.
data: | Year | % Children in Std V who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std V who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std V who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std VIII who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std VIII who can read Std II level text | % Children in Std VIII who can read Std II level text |
| Year | Govt | Pvt | Govt & Pvt* | Govt | Pvt | Govt & Pvt* |

title: Table 7: % Children by grade and arithmetic level. All children. 2024
description: This table evaluates the foundational arithmetic skills of students in India for the year 2024. It details the percentage of children in each grade, from Standard I to VIII, who have achieved different levels of numeracy, including number recognition, subtraction, and division.
data: | Std | Not even 1-9 | Recognize 1-9 | Recognize 11-99 | Subtraction | Division | Total |

title: Table 8: Trends over time
description: This table illustrates the change in basic arithmetic skills for Standard III students in India over several years (2014, 2016, 2018, 2022, 2024). It specifically measures the percentage of students in Standard III who can correctly perform at least a subtraction problem, with separate data points for government, private, and all school types combined.
data: | Year | % Children in Std III who can do at least subtraction | % Children in Std III who can do at least subtraction | % Children in Std III who can do at least subtraction |

title: Table 9: Trends over time
description: This table provides a historical comparison of arithmetic proficiency for students in Standards V and VIII in India. It charts the percentage of students in these grades who are able to solve a division problem for the years 2014, 2016, 2018, 2022, and 2024. The data is disaggregated by government schools, private schools, and the combined total.
data: | Year | % Children in Std V who can do division | % Children in Std V who can do division | % Children in Std V who can do division | % Children in Std VIII who can do division | % Children in Std VIII who can do division | % Children in Std VIII who can do division |

title: Table 10: Smartphone availability and use. By age. 2024
description: This table examines smartphone access and usage among older children (ages 14-16) in India for the year 2024. It presents data on the percentage of children who have a smartphone at home, those who could bring one for a task, their self-reported ability to use a smartphone, and the rate of personal smartphone ownership among those who can use one.

| Age | Have a smart-phone at home | Could bring a smartphone to do digital tasks* | Can use a smartphone | Of those who can use a smartphone, % who have their own smartphone |

title: Table 11: Smartphone availability and use among 14-16-year-olds. By sex. 2024
description: This table provides a gender-based comparison of smartphone access and usage among 14-16-year-olds in India for 2024. It details the percentage of boys and girls who have a smartphone at home, could bring one for a task, can use one, and the rate of personal smartphone ownership among users, highlighting digital access disparities between sexes.

| Sex | Have a smartphone at home | Could bring a smartphone to do digital tasks* | Can use a smart-phone | Of those who can use a smartphone, % who have their own smartphone |

title: Table 12: Of those who know how to use a smartphone, % children who used a smartphone in the reference week for any educational activity and social media activity, and know how to use safety features. By age. 2024
description: This table analyzes the digital behavior of smartphone-literate children in India for 2024, broken down by age (14, 15, and 16). It shows the percentage who used their smartphone for educational purposes and social media during the survey week, and details their awareness of key online safety features like blocking profiles, making profiles private, and changing passwords.

description: This table compares the digital activities and safety awareness of smartphone-literate boys and girls aged 14-16 in India for 2024. It presents the percentage of each sex who used a smartphone for educational and social media activities, and their proficiency with online safety measures such as blocking a profile, setting a profile to private, and changing a password.

title: Table 14: % Children who could do digital tasks, by age and sex. 2024
description: This table provides a detailed assessment of practical digital skills among Indian children aged 14-16 for the year 2024, with data disaggregated by both age and sex. It measures the percentage of children who could perform specific tasks on a smartphone, including setting an alarm, browsing for information, finding a YouTube video, and sharing the discovered video.

title: Table 17: Trends over time
description: This table shows the historical trend in the number of schools surveyed in India for the years 2010, 2018, 2022, and 2024. The data is broken down by school level, showing the count of primary schools and upper primary schools visited, along with the total number of schools included in the survey each year.

title: Table 18: Trends over time
description: This table tracks the average attendance rates for both students and teachers in India from 2010 to 2024. It presents the percentage of enrolled children present and the percentage of teachers present on the day of the visit, with separate trend data provided for primary and upper primary schools.

title: Table 19: Trends over time
description: This table shows the trend in the proportion of small schools in India from 2010 to 2024. It specifically details the percentage of primary and upper primary schools that have a total student enrollment of 60 or fewer, highlighting changes in school size over this period.

title: Table 20: Multigrade classes. 2024
description: This table focuses on the practice of teaching multigrade classes in Indian schools for the year 2024. It shows the percentage of primary and upper primary schools where children in Standard I and Standard II were observed sitting and being taught together with students from other grades.
data: | % Schools | Std I children  observed sitting with any other Std | Std II children  observed sitting with any other Std |

title: Table 21: Observation of TLM (Teaching Learning Materials) in classrooms. 2024
description: This table assesses the use of Teaching Learning Materials (TLM) beyond textbooks in Indian classrooms for 2024. It shows the percentage of primary and upper primary schools where TLM was observed in Standard I and II classrooms, and further details the proportion of those schools that also display student-created work.
data: | % Schools | TLM observed in classroom (apart from textbooks) | TLM observed in classroom (apart from textbooks) | Of those schools with TLM, work done by students displayed in classroom | Of those schools with TLM, work done by students displayed in classroom |
| % Schools | Std I | Std II | Std I | Std II |

title: Table 22: Trends over time
description: This table provides a detailed longitudinal overview of essential school facilities and resources in India from 2010 to 2024. It tracks the trends in the provision and usability of mid-day meals, drinking water, toilets (including separate facilities for girls), libraries, electricity connections, and computers for student use.

title: Table 23: Foundational Literacy and Numeracy (FLN) activities. 2024
description: This table details the implementation of India's Foundational Literacy and Numeracy (FLN) mission for the 2023-24 and 2024-25 academic years. It measures the extent to which primary and upper primary schools have received government directives, provided teacher training (offline and online), received teaching materials, and conducted School Readiness Programmes for Standard I.
